Use Case: Glimmer (Gene Locator and Interpolated Markov ModelER) is widely used for identifying genes in bacterial, archaeal, and viral genomes. 

Code Details and Examples: 

Firstly, the input file for Glimmer should be a FASTA formatted sequence file. 

Sample input format for a FASTA file:

```
>SEQ_ID

```
In this sample, ">SEQ_ID" is the label of the sequence, and the following text until the next ">" character (not shown) is the sequence data.

To use Glimmer, you would generally follow a series of steps:

```
#First, you would build an interpolated context model (ICM) of your sequence:
build-icm -r my_model.icm < g3-from-seq.in

#Then use this model to predict genes, with the -r option indicating that the model was built in reverse:
glimmer3 -o50 -g110 -t30 my_model.icm sequence.fasta predictions
```
In the above code snippets, "my_model.icm" is the output model, "sequence.fasta" is your input sequence, and "predictions" is the file where gene coordinates will be stored. 

Please note that these steps are greatly simplified and the specific options used will depend on your sequence and project needs.
